text:
I'm Dr. Graham Lieberman,
co-founder of FastLine,
along with Dr. Hilary Gallin.

FastLine is a
medical device that

makes the placement of
central venous lines,

kind of like super-powered
IVs, easier, faster, and safer.

A few years ago,
we had a patient,

we'll call her Sandra, who
was admitted to our ICU.

And as part of her treatment,
we placed a central venous line
into her neck.

Only this time, we accidentally
missed her jugular vein,

and we placed the line
into her carotid artery.
The result, Sandra had a stroke.
And a few days later, she died.

Every year, half
a million patients

are injured from central
lines that are placed wrong.

The reason is, the
way in which we

place them was never
originally designed

to do so, leading to a
procedure with poor ergonomics,

easily-skipped safety
checks, and one

that is incompatible with
continuous ultrasound guidance.

FastLine lets you place a
line with optimal ergonomics,

automatic safety checks,
and is compatible
with continuous ultrasound.

A hundred surgeons
and anesthesiologists
have tested FastLine.

Almost all of them now ask us
regularly, incessantly even,

when FastLine will be
clinically available.

We've proven that
FastLine works in pigs.

It doesn't defy the
laws of physics.

It will solve this
$3-billion-a-year problem.

We just need to get
FastLine through the FDA

to get it to the finish
line, at which point,

it'll mean that next time,
Sandra gets to go home.
Thank you very much.
